body:
That's interesting. I'm guessing it's most likely an issue with Stata 13, since I've only tested it with Stata 14 and 15.

I don't think I'll be able to get a copy of Stata 13 for me to test with, so I'll create a Git branch with possible fixes for you to try out. 

With the nature of the output, I'm guessing that it's a Windows end-of-line issue. We currently only use `\n` to delimit multiple lines; while Windows usually uses `\r\n` it hasn't been an issue with Stata 15 on Windows. 

I'm on a plane at the moment with mobile-only access, but tomorrow I'll create a branch for you to try.
I'm on Stata 13/IC on linux and don't see this, but I'm on 1.4.2... I wonder if it's related to line endings.
Thanks. I'm assuming it's a Windows end of line issue

@bermudaparty  Can you try 
```
pip install git+https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel@windows-crlf --upgrade
```

Ok, I ran the upgrade (just this one command, nothing else) and then again my test.do.

### Unrelated Error
First I ran into the following error (reported in Atom). Which had previously not happened (and I don't think I've tampered with anything since yesterday).
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main "main", mod_spec)
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code exec(code, run_globals)
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\stata_kernel__main__.py", line 4, in IPKernelApp.launch_instance(kernel_class=StataKernel)
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\traitlets\config\application.py", line 657, in launch_instance app.initialize(argv)
File "", line 2, in initialize File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\traitlets\config\application.py", line 87, in catch_config_error return method(app, args, **kwargs)
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\kernelapp.py", line 476, in initialize self.init_kernel()
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\kernelapp.py", line 387, in init_kernel user_ns=self.user_ns,
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\traitlets\config\configurable.py", line 412, in instance inst = cls(args, **kwargs)
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\stata_kernel\kernel.py", line 33, in init self.stata = StataSession(self, self.conf)
File "C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\stata_kernel\stata_session.py", line 76, in init if (platform.system() == 'Windows') and (int(self.stata_version[:2]) < ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '. '
```

As a quick fix I went in and changed line 76 in `stata_session.py` to (since I know my stata version is 13):

```
        if (platform.system() == 'Windows') and (int(13) <
                                                 15):
```
## Cut off letters
After this the basic communication to Stata seems to be working again. However there is still  a problem with letters being cut off. It seems now it's always the first letter on the first line of a block of code that gets lost.

Stata output:
```
. d `"D:\mydrive\Dummy"'
"D:\mydrive\Dummy invalid name
r(198);

. set more on

. set pagesize 100

. set linesize 80

. clear all

. global stata_kernel_graph_counter = 0

. `finished_init_cmd'
.  i "`c(stata_version)'"
unrecognized command:  i
r(199);

. `done'
.  StataKernelCompletions
unrecognized command:  StataKernelCompletions
r(199);

. `bcc4869c9c119320f7af8a3981776720'
.  nclude C:/Users/username/.stata_kernel_cache/include.do
unrecognized command:  nclude
r(199);

. `d153f7e92925be994646fb8d0cd93cab'
.  StataKernelCompletions
unrecognized command:  StataKernelCompletions
r(199);

. `bcc4869c9c119320f7af8a3981776720'
```

I edited code that should fix the first issue.

I changed it to try adding a `\r` before every line. Can you test again?
Still the same as in my last comment (first line of each code block (I think?)).

This is a pretty crude fix but what if you add an empty space before every line? Stata doesn't care about that.

At least manually adding empty spaces at the beginning of each line in lines 63-70 in `stata_session.py` works (for those commands then).

Manually adding empty spaces for all lines 63-70 _shouldn't_ work because that text is passed through `dedent()` which means that all common leading whitespace on those lines is removed. Do you have different numbers of spaces on each line?

Oh, interesting. I'm afraid my understanding of python is quite rudimentary..

I did like this:
```
        init_cmd = """\
            adopath + `"{0}"\'
             cd `"{1}"\'
             set more on
             set pagesize 100
             set linesize {2}
             clear all
             global stata_kernel_graph_counter = 0
             `finished_init_cmd'
            """.format(adodir, os.getcwd(), self.linesize).rstrip()
```

But on a (for me) more exciting note, the following makes everything work (line 182):
`text = '\r' + '. ' + text`

I then get the below output in stata on executing my little test.do. Also adding more commands works fine. On the other hand, only `text = '\r' + ' ' + text` does not work.

```

. cd `"D:\myfolder\Dummy"'
D:\myfolder\Dummy

.  set more on

.  set pagesize 100

.  set linesize 80

.  clear all

.  global stata_kernel_graph_counter = 0

.  `finished_init_cmd'

.   di "`c(stata_version)'"
13

. `done'
.   _StataKernelCompletions
%varlist%

%globals%
stata_kernel_graph_counter S_ADO S_level F1 F2 F7 F8 S_StataMP S_StataSE S_FLAVO
> R S_OS S_OSDTL S_MACH
%scalars%

%matrices%


. `bcc4869c9c119320f7af8a3981776720'
.   mata : invtokens(st_dir("local", "macro", "*")')
  

. `08a286cef0dc100f5df674f2b5353f29'
.   include C:/Users/username/.stata_kernel_cache/include.do

. set obs 10000
obs was 0, now 10000

.   generate u1 = runiform()

. . `d153f7e92925be994646fb8d0cd93cab'
.   _StataKernelCompletions
%varlist%
u1
%globals%
stata_kernel_graph_counter S_ADO S_level F1 F2 F7 F8 S_StataMP S_StataSE S_FLAVO
> R S_OS S_OSDTL S_MACH
%scalars%

%matrices%


. `bcc4869c9c119320f7af8a3981776720'
.   mata : invtokens(st_dir("local", "macro", "*")')
  

. `08a286cef0dc100f5df674f2b5353f29'

```

> I did like this
That adds a space to all the lines _after_ the first one, since the latter ones are indented one space more than the first.

I'm guessing you could remove the `\r` and just have `'. ' + text`. But I think in more modern versions of Stata, then you would have two periods. I might figure out a way on Windows to only change this behavior on Stata 13 and earlier.

Note to self:
specifically, search the registry and use that to find which Stata version is installed.
@bermudaparty keep playing around using `text = '\r' + '. ' + text` and let me know if that works smoothly for you.

@kylebarron 
I tried uninstalling and reinstalling to see if it would then work for me too. I figured since I kinda messed up on my first install because I misunderstood the stata path warning message maybe it was actually me who changed something when trying to "fix" that non-issue.

And indeed, it now works out of the box for me too. But it seems that you changed some stuff anyway since your last comment? (1) I can't find `text = '\r' + text` anymore. (2) Running commands in Atom now doesn't open a Stata window anymore, whereas previously it did.

I uninstalled by running `pip uninstall stata_kernel` and deleting the .conf file.

---

On another note: When installing again I got the following error (which I quick-fixed by simply removing the { and } from install.py).

```
stata_kernel\install.py", line 82, in install_conf
    """.format(stata_path, execution_mode))
ValueError: Single '}' encountered in format string
```

> I can't find `text = '\r' + text` anymore.

That's because this was added under a specific branch of code. That's why I had asked you to do `pip install git+https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel@windows-crlf --upgrade`.

> Running commands in Atom now doesn't open a Stata window anymore, whereas previously it did.

Likewise this is a change in the master branch.

> When installing again I got the following error

This is a bug; I should really test running `install.py` along with other automated tests...

I fixed the installing bug.

Good to hear it's working for you. Reopen if you have more issues.

I listed these observations because it seemed weird to me to just say "the bug never existed" simply because I wasn't able to reproduce it in a newer version. So I did a small experiment, and voilà:

If i revert to `self.automate(cmd_name='UtilShowStata', value=2)` (#131)  the behavior is back as it was when I opened this issue. I figured this might be useful information to you. No need to reopen for my sake though.

Thanks for your support and the whole project!



(Also, thanks for clarifying about `text = '\r' + text`. I was aware that you made me install from another branch, but not that that line had only been in there. Although in hindsight it makes sense that having `text = text` before adding `'\r' +` would have been pointless.. :) .)
So if the only thing you change is `1` to `2` in `self.automate(cmd_name='UtilShowStata', value=2)`, the problem returns?
Yes
Well in that case the error is in Stata's automation code. It's good this works, but in general I think I won't spend much effort to try to support Stata 13 and earlier.
